sub_topic: Prove that every group of order 12 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C12, the alternating group A4, or the dihedral group D6.
message_1: Let G be a group of order 12. Show that G must be isomorphic to either the cyclic group C12, the alternating group A4, or the dihedral group D6. Provide a detailed proof for each case.
message_2:
To show that G must be isomorphic to either C12, A4, or D6, we will consider the possible structures of G based on the Sylow theorems.

Recall that the order of G is 12, which can be factored as 2^2 * 3. By the Sylow theorems, we know that the number of 2-Sylow subgroups (n_2) must divide 3 and be congruent to 1 mod 2, and the number of 3-Sylow subgroups (n_3) must divide 4 and be congruent to 1 mod 3. Thus, n_2 can be 1 or 3, and n_3 can be 1 or 4.

Case 1: n_2 = 1 and n_3 = 1
If there is only one 2-Sylow subgroup and one 3-Sylow subgroup, then both are normal in G. Let P be the unique 2-Sylow subgroup and Q be the unique 3-Sylow subgroup. Since P and Q are normal, their product PQ is also a subgroup of G. Moreover, since the orders of P and Q are relatively prime (|P| = 4 and |Q| = 3), we have |PQ| = |P| * |Q| = 12. Thus, PQ = G, and G is the internal direct product of P and Q. Since P is of order 4 and Q is of order 3, both P and Q are cyclic, so G is isomorphic to the cyclic group C12.

Case 2: n_2 = 3 and n_3 = 1
If there are three 2-Sylow subgroups and one 3-Sylow subgroup, then the 3-Sylow subgroup Q is normal in G. Let P_1, P_2, and P_3 be the distinct 2-Sylow subgroups. Since the index of the 2-Sylow subgroups is 3, which is the smallest prime divisor of |G|, at least one of the 2-Sylow subgroups is normal in G (by a corollary of the Sylow theorems). Without loss of generality, let P_1 be normal in G. Then, the product P_1Q is a subgroup of G, and since |P_1| = 4 and |Q| = 3, we have |P_1Q| = 12. Thus, P_1Q = G, and G is the internal direct product of P_1 and Q. Since P_1 is of order 4 and Q is of order 3, both P_1 and Q are cyclic, so G is isomorphic to the dihedral group D6.

Case 3: n_2 = 1 and n_3 = 4
If there is only one 2-Sylow subgroup and four 3-Sylow subgroups, then the 2-Sylow subgroup P is normal in G. Let Q_1, Q_2, Q_3, and Q_4 be the distinct 3-Sylow subgroups. Since the index of the 3-Sylow subgroups is 3, which is the smallest prime divisor of |G|, at least one of the 3-Sylow subgroups is normal in G (by a corollary of the Sylow theorems). However, this leads to a contradiction, as there cannot be two distinct normal 3-Sylow subgroups in G (otherwise, their product would be a subgroup of order 9, which is impossible in a group of order 12). Thus, this case cannot occur.

Case 4: n_2 = 3 and n_3 = 4
If there are three 2-Sylow subgroups and four 3-Sylow subgroups, then neither the 2-Sylow nor the 3-Sylow subgroups are normal in G. In this case, G cannot be a direct product of its Sylow subgroups. However, we can still analyze the structure of G using the action of G on its 3-Sylow subgroups by conjugation. This action gives rise to a homomorphism from G to the symmetric group S_4. The kernel of this homomorphism is the intersection of the normalizers of the 3-Sylow subgroups, which is a normal subgroup of G. Since G is not a direct product of its Sylow subgroups, this kernel is nontrivial, and its order must be a divisor of 12. The only possibilities are 2, 3, or 4. If the order of the kernel is 2 or 3, then the order of the image of the homomorphism is 6 or 4, respectively, which is impossible since the image must be a subgroup of S_4, and S_4 has no subgroups of order 6 or 4. Thus, the order of the kernel must be 4, and the order of the image is 3. This implies that G is isomorphic to a subgroup of S_4 of order 12, which is the alternating group A4.

In conclusion, G must be isomorphic to either the cyclic group C12, the alternating group A4, or the dihedral group D6.
